CatDescriptText: Miss Joceyln Davis, children's party coordinator, North Side and Mr. Elmer Williams, laundromat owner, 618 Herron Avenue, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 28, 1962, pg. 11 with question: "As a newspaper reader, what type of stories have the greatest appeal to you; In other words, which stories do you read first?"   Ms. Davis' answer reads: "The stores which have the greatest appeal to me are those which have the interest of children because i work with children. As for my second choice, well, I image it's "Who's Who," or the Ladies Pages."  Mr. Williams' answer reads: "I would say the most appealing news to me is that which concerns the community.  I'm interested in this because it seems in these times of integration we don't want to be left without a community to integrate, where our business will fall so low, we won't be able to meet the competitor...I would say the main type of news concerning me is news of economics, the business world, and then the world situation."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Joceyln Davis wearing light colored cardigan sweater and light colored pinstriped skirt, standing in doorway of store; Portrait of Elmer Williams wearing light colored short sleeved shirt, standing in front of store with sign reading "...will...them..."
